fifthch.description: Carrying of a large format book.

fifthch.description: Applying a sticker label with a letter and numbers to indicate the shelf the book will occupy. Then the books are loaded on a cart to be shelved.
fifthch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/i0RVSZ_yDjs?start=675&end=698rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

fifthch.description: These static portraitures showing areas of the library for different types of content was alluded to in Cold Storage with worker portraits in areas signifying caution within the warehouse.
fifthch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/i0RVSZ_yDjs?start=342&end=353rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

fifthch.description: This shot is of the ceiling of the Oval Reading Room at the Richelieu Site of the Bibliotheque National de France (French National Library). The towering grandeur was illustrative of Sarah Thomas' point that in the past, libraries were often thought of as monumental "shrines to knowledge."
fifthch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/i0RVSZ_yDjs?start=215&end=221rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

fifthch.description: Every picture is stored, like a museum, as is the case in the medals room in which Louis XIV was among the first collectors. These images were paired with Matthew Sheehy's comment that we need to be asking what all the libraries are storing and ask "what commitment we have to the cultural and scientific heritage of our country."
fifthch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/i0RVSZ_yDjs?start=289&end=311rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

fifthch.description: Like a mausoleum, these items appear almost an interred underground.
fifthch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/i0RVSZ_yDjs?start=113&end=130rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

fifthch.description: The databases of the past weren't as spacially efficient as in the contemporary computer age.
fifthch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/i0RVSZ_yDjs?start=645&end=674rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

fifthch.description: How has the function of a library as civic space changed and how will it continue to change?
fifthch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/i0RVSZ_yDjs?start=1151&end=1190rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

fifthch.description: Mail couriers to the French National Library against Maurice Jarre's musical nod to "Singing in the Rain." Part of the extended network of systems that constitute libraries as systems storing and circulating periodicals, documents and books.
fifthch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/i0RVSZ_yDjs?start=431&end=442rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
<iframe width="492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/i0RVSZ_yDjs?start=592&end=610rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

fifthch.description: In the cross-cutting montage beginning at 19:26 in Cold Storage, this shot was constrasted against the exterior of the roof of the Harvard Depository.
fifthch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/i0RVSZ_yDjs?start=173&end=181rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

fifthch.description: In the cross-cutting montage beginning at 19:26 in Cold Storage, this hand-carried accession package to the French National Library is contrasted with the scores of heavy bins the staff must wrangle, usually on mechanized lifts due to sheer volume of materials.
fifthch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/i0RVSZ_yDjs?start=537&end=560rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

fifthch.description: In the cross-cutting montage beginning at 19:26 in Cold Storage, the opening of the paper-wrapped parcel is compared to the opening of the reusable plastic bin.
fifthch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/i0RVSZ_yDjs?start=215&end=221rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

fifthch.description: In the cross-cutting montage beginning at 19:26 in Cold Storage, both the French National Library and the Harvard Depository show their respective style and scale of extensive shelving.
fifthch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/i0RVSZ_yDjs?start=237&end=250rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

fifthch.description: In the cross-cutting montage beginning at 19:26 in Cold Storage, the French National Library shows its winding staircases while the Harvard Depository shows its direct ascent via order picker lift.
fifthch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/i0RVSZ_yDjs?start=699&end=704rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

fifthch.description: In the cross-cutting montage beginning at 19:26 in Cold Storage, the French National Library shows its enclosed rising via elevator while the Harvard Depository shows its open cab ascent via order picker lift.
fifthch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/i0RVSZ_yDjs?start=738&end=755rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

fifthch.description: In the cross-cutting montage beginning at 19:26 in Cold Storage, the French National Library shows a book traveling horizontally via cart, while the Harvard Depository shows an item descending diagonally on a order picker bed.
fifthch.location: <iframe width="492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/i0RVSZ_yDjs?start=711&end=717rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

fifthch.description: “Books are sorted by size and stored in specially designed trays and stored at right angles to the 36-inch-deep shelves. The trays are shelved two deep—one behind the other. Using book trays of varying sizes permits higher storage densities because books can be stored not only by height, but also by width."
fifthch.location:
<iframe width=“492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/jbaWD0t0v1k
?start=149&end=170rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

fifthch.description:
“When the boxes are unpacked, the barcoded materials from each client are kept separate. Books are measured using a template and put in barcoded book trays according to size. After a physical count is made of the books in each tray, the trays are loaded onto carts and brought to the process station. Here barcode numbers for each tray and the books in it are scanned into the computer system. This initiates the electronic association for each item of the unique client barcode with the unique Depository tray barcode. 

When all of the trays on a cart have been processed, the cart is moved to the expedite station. Again, the barcodes of each tray and books associated with it are scanned into the system. This second scan is compared to the first by the computer system and any discrepancies are brought to the attention of the system operator. 

The warehouse manager keeps a chart of locations in the stack area indicating the shelves occupied by each client’s material. Using this chart, the manager produces location sheets indicating where each tray containing new accessions should be shelved. 

Carts are brought into the warehouse and the trays are loaded onto a Raymond lift. Trays are then shelved according to the location sheets."
fifthch.location:
<iframe width=“492" height="277" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/jbaWD0t0v1k
?start=210&end=288rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

fifthch.description: “The barcodes of all items to be retrieved are keyed into the computer system, which produces a ‘pick list’ in order of location, saving time during retrieval and making the most efficient use of the Raymond lift.”
fifthch.location:
"<iframe width=“492"" height=""277"" src=""https://www.youtube.com/embed/jbaWD0t0v1k
?start=324&end=368rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0"" frameborder=""0"" allowfullscreen></iframe>"

fifthch.description: “The Depository may experiment with alternative modes of delivery including fax and other electronic forms.” The Depository today offers a "Scan & Deliver" service that allows students, faculty, staff, summer school students and special borrowers to request and obtain electronically scanned portions of certain items from the library collections that are currently on the shelf.
fifthch.location:
"<iframe width=“492"" height=""277"" src=""https://www.youtube.com/embed/jbaWD0t0v1k
?start=400&end=406rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0"" frameborder=""0"" allowfullscreen></iframe>"

fifthch.description: “Since its opening in 1986, use of the Depository continues to expand and grow. A new unit is likely to be constructed every 4-5 years as library storage needs dictate.” In reality, the Depository would open a 3rd and a 4th module in less than 4 years, with five total additional modules (3,4,5,6, & B) within just 10 years of the video’s release. Module 7 would open in 2009.
fifthch.location:
"<iframe width=“492"" height=""277"" src=""https://www.youtube.com/embed/jbaWD0t0v1k
?start=672&end=684rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0"" frameborder=""0"" allowfullscreen></iframe>"

fifthch.description: The Depository had only two modules back in 1993.
fifthch.location:
"<iframe width=“492"" height=""277"" src=""https://www.youtube.com/embed/jbaWD0t0v1k
?start=79&end=88rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0"" frameborder=""0"" allowfullscreen></iframe>"

fifthch.description: Bin n. (1) A box, frame, crib, or enclosed place used for storage. (2) A color-coded plastic container used for van transport to and from the Harvard Depository: a gray bin signifies new contents not yet on file; a red bin signifies existing circulating materials in the process of leaving or returning.
